documents.title: EU Regulation 1169/2011 - Food Information to Consumers
documents.content:
# EU Regulation 1169/2011 - Food Information to Consumers

## Introduction

Regulation (EU) No. 1169/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2011 establishes a comprehensive framework for providing information about food to consumers. The regulation modifies previous directives and introduces modern labeling requirements that reflect consumer needs for transparency and accurate information.

The document presented constitutes a documentation tool and does not have legal force. The authentic texts are published in the Official Journal of the European Union (OJ L 304 of 22.11.2011, p. 18).

## Basic Content

### Purpose and Application

The regulation sets requirements for providing food information to consumers, aiming to:

- Protect the health and interests of consumers
- Provide accurate, clear, and understandable information
- Empower consumers to make informed choices

### Main Amendments to Regulations

This regulation amends:
- Regulation (EC) No. 1924/2006 on health claims
- Regulation (EC) No. 1925/2006 on added vitamins and minerals

And repeals:
- Directive 87/250/EEC of the Commission
- Directive 90/496/EEC of the Council
- Directive 1999/10/EC of the Commission
- Directive 2000/13/EC of the European Parliament and Council
- Directives 2002/67/EC and 2008/5/EC of the Commission
- Regulation (EC) No. 608/2004 of the Commission

## Amendment History

The regulation has been amended multiple times:

| Amendment | Number | Date |
|---|---|---|
| Delegated Regulation | 1155/2013 | 16.11.2013 |
| Delegated Regulation | 78/2014 | 30.1.2014 |
| Regulation | 2015/2283 | 11.12.2015 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2024/2512 | 25.9.2024 |

## Corrections

The regulation has been corrected by the following corrections:
- Corrigendum OJ L 266 of 30.9.2016
- Corrigendum OJ L 142 of 1.6.2023
- Corrigendum OJ L 214 of 31.8.2023

## Key Information for Consumers

The regulation establishes obligations for:

1. **Mandatory Information** that must be provided for all pre-packed foods
2. **Food Name** in a clear and definitely visible manner
3. **List of Ingredients** with description of allergens
4. **Quantitative Declaration of Ingredients** (QUID) where required
5. **Net Weight or Volume** of the food
6. **Date of Expiry or Consumption Date**
7. **Storage Conditions** and instructions for use
8. **Business Details** (name and address)

## Purpose of the Regulation

The regulation aims to ensure that:
- Consumers have access to accurate information
- Labeling is clear and understandable
- Misleading practices are prevented
- Public health is protected

## Scope of Application

The regulation applies to:
- All pre-packed foods
- Foods placed on the market in the European Union
- Foods that are imported or exported

The regulation does not apply to:
- Non-pre-packed foods (unless national rules are adopted)
- Foods packaged at the point of sale or prepared for immediate sale

## Observations

The current version is an updated summary of the regulation as of 1 April 2025 and includes all amendments and corrections up to that date.

---
**Current Version**: 01.04.2025

documents.title: EU Regulation 1308/2013 - Common Organization of Agricultural Markets
documents.content:
# EU Regulation 1308/2013 - Common Organization of Agricultural Markets

## Introduction

Regulation (EU) No. 1308/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013 establishes the common organization of the markets in agricultural products. It constitutes the fundamental legal framework for the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) of the European Union and defines the rules for market intervention in agricultural products.

The regulation was published in OJ L 347 of 20.12.2013, p. 671 and is a documentation tool that is updated regularly.

## Scope of Application

### Agricultural Products

The regulation establishes common market organization for all products included in Annex I of the Treaties, with the exception of:
- Fishery and aquaculture products

### Sectors of Application

Agricultural products are subdivided into the following sectors:

| Sector | Part | Description |
|---|---|---|
| Cereals | Part I | Wheat, barley, maize, etc. |
| Rice | Part II | Rice and derived products |
| Sugar | Part III | White and raw sugar |
| Dried Fodder | Part IV | Herbaceous fodder |
| Seeds for Sowing | Part V | Seeds for agricultural production |
| Hops | Part VI | Hops for beer |
| Olive Oil | Part VII | Olive oil and table olives |
| Flax and Hemp | Part VIII | Plant fibers |
| Vegetables and Fruit | Part IX | Fruits and vegetables |
| Bananas | Part XI | Tropical fruits |
| Wine | Part XII | Wine |
| Beef and Veal | Part XV | Slaughtered bovines |
| Milk and Dairy | Part XVI | Dairy products |
| Pigmeat | Part XVII | Slaughtered pigs |
| Sheepmeat and Goatmeat | Part XVIII | Slaughtered goats/sheep |
| Eggs | Part XIX | Chicken eggs |
| Poultry Meat | Part XX | Chicken and other poultry |

## Marketing Periods

Different marketing periods are established for various product categories:

- **1 January - 31 December**: Vegetables and fruit, processed vegetables and fruit, bananas
- **1 April - 31 March**: Dried fodder, silkworms
- **1 July - 30 June**: Cereals, seeds, flax/hemp, milk
- **1 August - 31 July**: Wine sector
- **1 September - 31 August**: Rice, table olives
- **1 October - 30 September**: Sugar, olive oil

## Reference Prices

The regulation establishes reference prices for major agricultural products:

| Product | Reference Price | Unit | Notes |
|---|---|---|---|
| Cereals | 101.31 | €/tonne | Wholesale sale, delivered to warehouse |
| Husked Rice | 150 | €/tonne | Specific quality type |
| White Sugar | 404.4 | €/tonne | Unpackaged, at factory gate |
| Raw Sugar | 335.2 | €/tonne | Unpackaged, at factory gate |
| Beef | 2,224 | €/tonne | Male bovine slaughter class R3 |
| Butter | 246.39 | €/100kg | Dairy product |
| Skimmed Milk Powder | 169.80 | €/100kg | Powdered milk |
| Pigmeat | 1,509.39 | €/tonne | Slaughtered pigs of specific type |
| Extra Virgin Olive Oil | 1,779 | €/tonne | Highest quality |
| Virgin Olive Oil | 1,710 | €/tonne | Medium quality |
| Lampante Olive Oil | 1,524 | €/tonne | With acidity of two degrees |

## Amendments and History

The regulation has undergone significant amendments:

| Regulation | Number | Date |
|---|---|---|
| Regulation | 1310/2013 | 20.12.2013 |
| Regulation | 2016/791 | 24.5.2016 |
| Regulation | 2017/2393 | 29.12.2017 |
| Regulation | 2020/2220 | 28.12.2020 |
| Regulation | 2021/2117 | 6.12.2021 |
| Regulation | 2024/1143 | 23.4.2024 |

## Market Interventions

### Public Intervention

The regulation provides for market intervention in the form of:
- Public intervention (public buying)
- Private storage aid

### Purpose

Interventions aim to:
- Stabilize markets
- Support agricultural community
- Ensure farmer incomes

## General CAP Provisions

For measures provided in this regulation, Regulation (EU) 2021/2116 applies regarding:
- Financing
- Management
- Monitoring of the Common Agricultural Policy

## Definitions

The regulation contains detailed definitions for:
- **Less developed regions**: Regions as defined in related regulation annexes
- **Adverse weather phenomena**: Conditions such as frost, hail, ice that destroy more than 30% of production

## Commission Reporting Requirements

The regulation establishes the Commission's obligation to submit reports on:
- Application of competition rules in agriculture (every seven years)
- Use of market crisis measures (every three years)
- EU market observatories
- New technologies for market transparency

## Important Notes

1. The regulation replaces previous legal texts on agricultural markets
2. Provides a unified framework for all EU member states
3. Ensures fair competitive order
4. Supports the agricultural community
5. Is regularly updated to adapt to changing market conditions

---
**Last Updated**: 08.11.2024

documents.title: EU Regulation 2018/848 - Organic Production and Labeling
documents.content:
# EU Regulation 2018/848 - Organic Production and Labeling

## Introduction

Regulation (EU) 2018/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 May 2018 establishes the principles of **organic production** and the rules regarding organic production, related certification, and the use of indications related to organic production in labeling and advertising.

The regulation was published in OJ L 150 of 14.6.2018, p. 1 and repeals the previous Regulation (EC) No. 834/2007.

## Scope of Application

### Products Covered

This regulation applies to products originating from the agricultural sector, including:

1. **Primary Production Products**:
   - Live or unprocessed agricultural products
   - Seeds and other plant reproductive material
   - Aquaculture products
   - Beekeeping products

2. **Processed Products**:
   - Processed agricultural products for use as food
   - Products included in Annex I

3. **Animal Feed**:
   - Animal feed for use in organic production

4. **Related Products**:
   - Products closely linked to agriculture
   - As referred to in Annex I of the regulation
   - E.g. essential oils, yeast

### Exclusions from Scope

**Mass catering** (catering):
- Not fully subject to the regulation
- Member states may apply national rules
- The EU organic production logo is not used

## Subject Matter of the Regulation

The regulation establishes:

1. **Principles of Organic Production**:
   - Conservation of biodiversity
   - Preservation of soil quality
   - Prevention and control of harmful organisms
   - Avoidance of negative environmental impacts

2. **Production Rules**:
   - At all stages of production
   - Processing and distribution

3. **Certification**:
   - Organic product certification procedures
   - Controls supplementary to Regulation (EU) 2017/625 rules

4. **Labeling and Advertising**:
   - Use of organic production indications
   - EU logo for organic production
   - Labeling policies

## Key Definitions

### Organic Production
The use of production methods in accordance with the regulation at all stages:
- Production
- Processing
- Distribution
- (Including the conversion period)

### Organic Product
A product originating from organic production, **excluding** products produced during the conversion period.

**Note**: Wild-caught fish or game are not considered organic products.

### Agricultural Raw Material
An agricultural product that has not been subject to any preservation or processing work.

### Conversion
The transition from non-organic to organic production within a certain time period during which the regulation's provisions are applied.

### Farm/Holding
All production units operating under single management with the aim of producing:
- Live or unprocessed agricultural products
- Aquaculture products
- Beekeeping products

## Production Units

### Organic Production Unit
A production unit (outside conversion period) managed in accordance with organic production requirements.

### Conversion Unit
A production unit during the conversion period managed in accordance with organic production requirements. May consist of fields or other assets with different conversion start dates.

### Non-Organic Production Unit
A production unit not managed in accordance with organic production requirements.

## Plant and Animal Products

### Plant Production
Production of agricultural crop products, including harvesting of wild plants for commercial purposes.

### Animal Production
Production of:
- Domesticated or tamed terrestrial animals
- Including insects

### Veranda/Covered Area
An additional, unheated, non-insulated external covered area of a building for poultry, typically wire-netted, open to external weather conditions, with natural and artificial lighting and bedded floor.

### Laying Hens
Animals of the species *Gallus gallus* intended for egg production at least 18 weeks of age.

## Plant Reproductive Material

### Organic Heterogeneous Material
A group of plants within a single botanical taxonomic unit that:
- Exhibits common phenotypic characteristics
- Is characterized by high genetic and phenotypic diversity level
- Is not a variety as defined in Regulation (EC) 2100/94
- Does not constitute a mixture of varieties
- Has been produced in accordance with this regulation

### Organic Variety Suitable for Organic Production
A variety that:
- Is characterized by high genetic and phenotypic diversity level
- Results from organic breeding activities

## Ingredients and Raw Materials

### Ingredient
- For food: as defined in Regulation (EU) 1169/2011
- For other products: any substance or product used in preparation/processing that continues to exist in the final product (even in modified form)

### Animal Feed Raw Materials
As defined in Regulation (EC) No. 767/2009

## Traceability

The ability to identify and track:
- Food products
- Animal feed
- Organic production products
- At all stages of production, processing and distribution

## Enterprise

A natural or legal person responsible for ensuring compliance with the regulation at all stages of production, processing and distribution that it controls.

## Regulation Amendments

The regulation has been amended multiple times:

| Regulation | Number | Date |
|---|---|---|
| Delegated Regulation | 2020/427 | 23.3.2020 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2021/269 | 22.2.2021 |
| Regulation | 2020/1693 | 13.11.2020 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2020/1794 | 1.12.2020 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2021/642 | 20.4.2021 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2021/715 | 3.5.2021 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2021/716 | 3.5.2021 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2021/1006 | 22.6.2021 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2021/1691 | 22.9.2021 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2021/1697 | 23.9.2021 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2022/474 | 25.3.2022 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2023/207 | 1.2.2023 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2024/2867 | 11.11.2024 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2025/405 | 26.2.2025 |
| Delegated Regulation | 2025/452 | 5.3.2025 |

## Corrections

The regulation has been corrected by the following corrigenda:
- Corrigendum OJ L 270 of 29.10.2018
- Corrigendum OJ L 305 of 26.11.2019
- Corrigendum OJ L 439 of 29.12.2020
- Corrigendum OJ L 7 of 11.1.2021
- Corrigendum OJ L 204 of 10.6.2021
- Corrigendum OJ L 318 of 9.9.2021

## Important Information

1. The regulation has broad scope of application covering all production stages
2. Provides unified legal framework for organic products in the EU
3. Includes detailed definitions of relevant terms
4. Establishes obligations for businesses and member states
5. Is regularly updated with delegated regulations

---
**Current Update Date**: 25.03.2025

documents.title: European Commission Notice on Allergen Information Labeling
documents.content:
# European Commission Notice on Allergen Information Labeling

## Document Information

- **Date**: 13 July 2017
- **Reference**: 2017/C 428/01
- **Subject**: Notice on the provision of information about substances or products causing allergies or intolerances listed in Annex II of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011

---

## Table of Contents

1. Introduction
2. List of Allergens (Annex II of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011)
3. Detailed method of providing allergen information in pre-packaged foods (specifically Article 21 in combination with Article 18 of the Regulation)
4. Allergen information in non-pre-packaged foods
5. Update of Annex II

---

## 1. Introduction

The purpose of this notice is to assist businesses and national authorities in implementing the new requirements of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 of the European Parliament and Council regarding the indication of the presence of certain substances or products causing allergies or intolerances [Article 9 paragraph 1 point (c) and Annex II of the Regulation].

Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 on the provision of food information to consumers establishes new requirements regarding the labeling of allergens compared to Directive 2000/13/EC of the European Parliament and Council.

Specifically, under the new legislation, information about the presence of allergens in foods must be provided to consumers at all times, including in non-pre-packaged foods (Article 9 paragraph 1 point (c) and Article 44). However, Member States are permitted to establish national measures regarding the method of providing allergen information in non-pre-packaged foods. Regarding pre-packaged foods, the Regulation specifies the detailed method of providing allergen information in foods (Article 21). Consequently, the existing guidelines for allergen labeling, which were drawn up under the framework of Directive 2000/13/EC, should be updated to reflect this change in legislation.

This notice does not affect the interpretation that may be provided by the Court of Justice of the European Union.

---

## 2. List of Allergens (Annex II of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011)

Annex II of the Regulation includes a list of substances or products contained in foods and cause allergies or intolerances. This list was prepared based on scientific opinions issued by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA).

Within the framework of Annex II, the following should be noted:

- **Cereals**: The cereals listed in Annex II point 1 should be considered as an exhaustive list.

- **Eggs**: The eggs in Annex II point 3 refer to eggs from farmed birds of any species.

- **Milk**: The milk in Annex II point 7 refers to milk from the mammary gland of farmed animals.

- **Tree Nuts**: The tree nuts listed in Annex II point 8 should be considered as an exhaustive list.

- **Derivatives**: Annex II lists not only substances and products as such but also products derived from them. If microorganisms are fed on a substrate that constitutes a food ingredient included in Annex II, such microorganisms should not be considered products derived from such substrates.

---

## 3. Detailed Method of Providing Allergen Information in Pre-Packaged Foods

### (Specifically Article 21 in combination with Article 18 of the Regulation)

#### 3.1. When the food has an ingredients list

According to Article 21 paragraph 1 point (a):

> "Subject to the rules laid down pursuant to Article 44 paragraph 2, the information provided for in Article 9 paragraph 1 point (c) shall meet the following requirements:
> (a) they are listed in the ingredients list in accordance with the rules of Article 18 paragraph 1, with a clear reference to the name of the substance or product as included in Annex II; [...]"

**Cereals containing gluten**: When ingredients are produced from cereals containing gluten listed in Annex II, they must be declared with a name that contains a clear reference to the specific type of cereal, namely wheat, rye, barley, or oats.

**Example**: Barley vinegar, oat flakes.

**Special wheat varieties**: When using spelt, Khorasan wheat, or durum wheat, there must be a clear reference to the specific type of cereal, meaning wheat must be written. The word wheat may be accompanied by the word "durum," "spelt," or "Khorasan," added optionally.

**Example**: Wheat or wheat (durum) or durum wheat, wheat or wheat (spelt) or spelt wheat.

The indication of the specific type of cereal may be accompanied by the word "gluten," added optionally.

**Example**: Wheat flour (contains gluten) or wheat flour (gluten).

**Pure gluten**: When gluten is added as such, as an ingredient, the type of cereal from which the gluten is derived must be declared.

**Example**: Gluten (wheat), wheat gluten, or gluten (from wheat); dextrin (wheat) or (wheat gluten); dextrin (contains wheat) or (contains wheat gluten).

**Gluten-free claims**: When a product containing one of the cereals mentioned in Annex II (e.g., oats) meets the relevant requirements of Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 828/2014, the product may use the claim "gluten-free" or "very low gluten content." However, the cereal mentioned in Annex II must in this case also be listed and emphasized in the ingredients list in accordance with Articles 9 and 21 of the Regulation.

**Tree nuts**: Regarding tree nuts, the specific type listed in Annex II point 8 must be stated in the ingredients list, namely almonds, hazelnuts, walnuts, cashew nuts, pecan nuts, Brazil nuts, pistachios, or macadamia nuts. When ingredients or food processing aids derive from tree nuts listed in Annex II, the ingredient must be declared with a clear reference to the specific name of the tree nut.

**Example**: Seasoning (almond).

#### Highlighting allergens

According to Article 21 paragraph 1 point (b):

> "[...] (b) the name of the substance or product as included in Annex II is emphasized by a type of character that makes a clear distinction of the name from the rest of the ingredients list, for example through the font, style, or background color".

Article 21 paragraph 1 point (b) provides some flexibility regarding the method of emphasis, for example through font, style, or background color. It is up to the food business operator to choose the appropriate method of distinguishing each allergen from the other ingredients in the list. However, some clarifications are needed regarding the information that must be emphasized.

**Partial names**: When the name of an ingredient consists of several separate words (e.g., in French "poudre de lait," "milk powder"), it is sufficient to emphasize only the word that corresponds to the substance/product listed in Annex II. When the allergen name is part of an ingredient name in a single word (e.g., in German "Milchpulver," "milk powder"), it is sufficient to emphasize the part of the ingredient name that corresponds to the substance/product listed in Annex II.

**Compound ingredients**: If a compound ingredient contains substances causing allergies or intolerances listed in Annex II, these substances must be emphasized in the ingredients list.

**Example**: For a banana cream containing egg yolk, strawberry, sugar, water, [...], the word "egg" must be emphasized. For a sandwich with mayonnaise containing eggs, the presence of "eggs" must be emphasized.

#### 3.2. When the food does not have an ingredients list

Article 21 paragraph 1 second subparagraph states:

> "If there is no ingredients list, the indication of the information provided for in Article 9 paragraph 1 point (c) includes the word 'contains', followed by the name of the substance or product as included in Annex II".

**Exception for foods used as ingredients**: When foods excluded from the requirement to carry an ingredients list (such as wine) are used as an ingredient in the production or preparation of another food that has an ingredients list, the presence of allergens in such foods must be emphasized so they stand out from the other ingredients in the list (Article 21 paragraph 1 applies).

**Example**: Ingredients: ... wine (contains sulfites), with the word "sulfites" emphasized.

#### 3.3. Labeling of derivatives of the same allergen

Article 21 paragraph 1 third subparagraph states:

> "Where various ingredients or food processing aids derive from a single substance or product listed in Annex II, this shall be made clear in the labeling for each relevant ingredient or food processing aid".

For the purposes of this requirement, the reference to the substance(s) or product(s) listed in Annex II does not necessarily need to be repeated as many times as these substances are present. Any presentation that makes clear that different ingredients derive from a single substance or product included in Annex II meets the requirement and is acceptable. However, the reference must be directly linked to the ingredients list, e.g., the relevant information is listed at the end of the ingredients list or very close to the ingredients list.

**Example**:
A food that includes food additives, carriers, and processing aids derived from wheat could be labeled as follows:

```
...
— Additive (1)
— Additive (1)
— Carrier (1)
— Processing aid (1)
— ...
(1) from wheat (with the word "wheat" emphasized).
```

#### 3.4. Exception

Article 21 paragraph 1 final subparagraph states:

> "The indication of the information referred to in Article 9 paragraph 1 point (c) shall not be required in cases where the name of the food clearly refers to the substance or product in question".

According to this requirement, when a food is sold under a name such as "cheese" or "cream," which clearly refers to one of the allergens listed in Annex II (e.g., milk) and the food is not required to carry an ingredients list in accordance with Article 19 paragraph 1 point (d) of the Regulation, the specific allergen need not be declared on the label.

However, if the food is sold under a trade name/commercial name that does not clearly refer to one of the allergens in Annex II, the commercial name should be accompanied by additional information that "clearly refers to" the relevant allergen, as required by Article 21 paragraph 1 final subparagraph.

**Example**:
"Ambert" (as the name of the food) together with "rustic blue cheese" (as text that complements the food name and is listed very close to the food name), where the word cheese is the clear reference to the substance in Annex II.

Because consumer understanding of such food names may differ from one Member State to another, case-by-case assessment is necessary.

**With ingredients list**: If the food name clearly refers to one of the allergens listed in Annex II and there is an ingredients list for that food (on either an optional or mandatory basis), the allergen present in the food must be emphasized in the ingredients list.

**Example**: "Cheese (milk, salt, rennet, ...)", with the word milk emphasized.

**Multiple allergens**: If the food name clearly refers to a substance or product in Annex II but the product contains other substances or products in Annex II, those allergens must be declared so that consumers can make informed choices about foods that are safe for them.

#### 3.5. Optional repetition

Except for existing Union provisions applicable to specific foods, allergen information cannot be optionally repeated outside the ingredients list; nor can the word "contains" be used followed by the name of the substance or product listed in Annex II; nor can symbols or boxes with text be used (see recital 47, Article 21 paragraph 1 in combination with Article 36 paragraph 1 of the Regulation).

---

## 4. Allergen Information in Non-Pre-Packaged Foods

Article 44 of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 states:

> "1. For foods offered for sale to the final consumer or to mass catering facilities without pre-packaging or foods packaged at the point of sale at the buyer's request, or pre-packaged for direct sale,
> (a) the provision of the information defined in Article 9 paragraph 1 point (c) is mandatory;
> [...]
> 2. Member States may lay down national measures concerning the manner in which the indications or elements of the indications defined in paragraph 1 are to be provided and, where appropriate, the form of expression and presentation of these indications".

The Regulation provides for mandatory provision of allergen information in non-pre-packaged foods.

**Member State discretion**: Member States, however, retain the authority to establish national provisions regarding the manner in which allergen information is provided in such foods. In principle, all means of communication are permitted regarding the provision of allergen information so that consumers can make informed choices, e.g., label, other accompanying material, or any other means, such as modern technology tools or oral announcements (i.e., verifiable oral information).

**Absence of national measures**: If no such national measures are established, the provisions of the Regulation for pre-packaged foods also apply to non-pre-packaged foods. Therefore, in accordance with Article 13 of the Regulation, allergen information must be easily visible, legible, and, as appropriate, indelible and provided in written form. For this reason, it is not possible to provide allergen information only when the consumer requests it. Furthermore, the labeling requirements defined in Article 21 of the Regulation (points 3-21 above) apply.

---

## 5. Update of Annex II

Article 21 paragraph 2 of the Regulation states:

> "In order to ensure better information for consumers and to take into account the latest scientific advances and technical knowledge, the Commission shall systematically review and, if necessary, update the list in Annex II by means of delegated acts in accordance with Article 51.
> [...]".

**Updating the allergen list**: The update of the list in Annex II may consist of adding a substance to the list or removing a substance from it. Regarding the removal from the list of food allergens, Directive 2000/13/EC provided special provisions under which interested parties could submit to the Commission studies demonstrating that for certain allergens it has been scientifically proven that it is impossible for them to cause adverse reactions. These special provisions have not been retained in the Regulation. However, this fact does not prevent potentially interested parties from notifying the Commission of information demonstrating that products derived from substances listed in Annex II are not likely, under certain conditions, to cause adverse reactions in individuals.

**Submission procedure**: Such information can be prepared in accordance with the EFSA document "Guidance on the preparation and presentation of applications pursuant to Article 6 paragraph 11 of Directive 2000/13/EC" and can be sent to the Commission in at least two copies on an electronic medium (CD or memory stick) to the following address:

> Directorate General for Health and Food Safety, Unit E1
> European Commission
> 1049 Bruxelles/Brussel
> BELGIQUE/BELGIË

---

## Document Metadata

- **Official Journal**: Official Journal of the European Union C 428/1, 13.12.2017
- **Language**: English (translated from Greek)
- **Regulation Reference**: Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 of the European Parliament and Council of 25 October 2011
- **Directive Reference**: Directive 2000/13/EC of the European Parliament and Council of 20 March 2000

documents.title: QUID Notice - Quantitative Ingredient Declaration (2017/C 393/05)
documents.content:
# QUID Notice - Quantitative Ingredient Declaration (2017/C 393/05)

## Introduction

This Commission Notice (2017/C 393/05) provides guidance on the application of the principle of quantitative ingredient declaration (QUID - Quantitative Ingredient Declaration) within the framework of Regulation (EU) No. 1169/2011.

The notice aims to provide guidance to:
- Food businesses
- National authorities

and replaces the previous guidance adopted under Directive 79/112/EEC.

## Obligation for Quantitative Ingredient Declaration

### General Principles

Regulation (EU) No. 1169/2011 requires the declaration of the quantity of certain ingredients or categories of ingredients used in the manufacture or processing of all **pre-packed foods**.

### Exceptions

Quantitative ingredient declaration **does not apply** in the following cases:

1. **Foods with Single Ingredient**: The quantity automatically corresponds to 100%

2. **Non-pre-packed Foods**: 
   - Foods offered without packaging
   - Foods packaged at the point of sale at the customer's request
   - Products pre-packaged for immediate sale
   - (Unless member states have adopted national rules)

3. **Special Cases**: As defined in Annex VIII of the Regulation

4. **Naturally Contained Elements**: 
   - Caffeine in coffee
   - Vitamins and mineral substances in fruit juices
   - (Have not been added as ingredients)

## Criteria for Quantitative Declaration

### Article 22 Paragraph 1 of the Regulation

Declaration of the quantity of an ingredient or category of ingredients is required when:

#### a) Appearance in Food Name

The ingredient appears in the food name **or** is normally associated by the consumer with the food name.

**Examples requiring QUID:**
- "Pizza with ham and mushrooms" → Ham, mushrooms
- "Strawberry yogurt" → Strawberry
- "Salmon mousse" → Salmon
- "Chocolate ice cream" → Chocolate
- "Vegetable pie" → Total vegetable content
- "Fish croquettes" → Total fish content

**Examples with ingredient categories:**
- Bread with dried fruit → Dried fruit
- Fruit tart → Fruit

### Compound Ingredients

For compound ingredients, the following rules apply:

#### Situation 1: Compound ingredient in the name
E.g. "Biscuits with cream filling"
→ **Required**: Quantitative declaration of cream filling ingredients

#### Situation 2: Ingredient of compound ingredient in the name
E.g. "Biscuits with cream filling containing eggs"
→ **Required**: Quantitative declaration for eggs, in addition to the cream filling

### b) Clear Distinction on Label

Declaration of quantity is required when the ingredient is clearly distinguished on the label by:
- Words
- Images
- Graphic representation

**Examples:**
- "With chicken"
- "Made with butter"
- "With cream"
- Different font size/color
- Photograph or illustration of specific ingredients
- Image indicating origin (e.g., cow image for dairy)

**Presentations NOT requiring QUID:**
- Photograph of the food as sold
- "Serving suggestion"
- Image representing all ingredients without focus on one
- Image showing preparation/serving method

### c) Essential Significance for Characterization

Declaration of quantity is required when the ingredient has essential significance for:
- Characterization of the food
- Distinction from similar products

This applies particularly when foods are described with **common names** without descriptive details.

## Examples of Common Names

| Common Name | Descriptive Name | Required QUID |
|---|---|---|
| Lancashire hot pot | Beef with potatoes, onions, carrots | Beef |
| Chilli con carne | Ground beef with beans, tomatoes, peppers | Ground beef |
| Forloren skildpadde | Beef with meatballs | Beef |
| Boudoir | Biscuits with eggs | Eggs |
| Brandade | Dish with potatoes and cod | Cod |
| Cassoulet | Dish with beans, sausages, meat | Meat |
| Königinpastete | Beef with asparagus and mushrooms in pastry | Beef |
| Gulaschsuppe | Soup with beef, onions and paprika | Beef |
| Hutspot | Dish primarily with carrots and onions | Carrots and onions |
| Kåldolmar | Cabbage leaves filled with ground meat and rice | Meat |

## Exceptions from QUID Declaration

**Not necessary** to declare ingredient quantity for:

- Apples in apple juice (confusion with product name)
- Dry ham (no automatic obligation for similar products to declare meat)

## Forms of Expression

Quantitative ingredient declaration can be expressed as:
- Percentage by weight (%)
- Absolute quantity
- Per case basis

## Position on Label

QUID must be placed:
- In the ingredient list or
- Near the food name
- Visible and legible

## Interpretation and Application

Important interpretation principles:

1. **Case-by-case assessment**: No automatic obligation for every name

2. **Reasonableness**: Logic should be used in relation to expected composition

3. **Consumer-centric standard**: Based on what consumers typically associate with the product

## Sources

- Regulation (EU) No. 1169/2011
- Notice 2017/C 393/05
- Work of the Directorate-General for Health and Food Safety (SANTE) of the Commission
- Work group with experts from member states

---
**Publication Date**: 21.11.2017
**Application**: Immediate to EU bodies and member states

documents.title: REGULATION (EU) No. 1308/2013
documents.content:
# REGULATION (EU) No. 1308/2013

**Adopted:** December 17, 2013

**Subject:** Establishing a common organisation of the markets in agricultural products and repealing Council Regulations (EEC) No. 922/72, (EEC) No. 234/79, (EC) No. 1037/2001 and (EC) No. 1234/2007

## PART I - INTRODUCTORY PROVISIONS

## ARTICLE 1 - Scope of Application

### 1. General Scope

This Regulation establishes the common organisation of the markets in agricultural products for all the products listed in Annex I to the Treaties, with the exception of fishery and aquaculture products as defined in the Union legislation on the common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products.

### 2. Agricultural Product Sectors

The agricultural products referred to in paragraph 1 are subdivided into the following sectors, as listed in the corresponding sections of Annex I:

- **a)** Cereals - Part I
- **b)** Rice - Part II
- **c)** Sugar - Part III
- **d)** Dried fodder - Part IV
- **e)** Seeds for sowing - Part V
- **f)** Hops - Part VI
- **g)** Olive oil and table olives - Part VII
- **h)** Flax and hemp - Part VIII
- **i)** Fruit and vegetables - Part IX
- **j)** Processed fruit and vegetable products - Part X
- **k)** Bananas - Part XI
- **l)** Wine - Part XII
- **m)** Live trees and other plants, bulbs, roots and similar products, cut flowers and ornamental foliage - Part XIII
- **n)** Tobacco - Part XIV
- **o)** Beef - Part XV
- **p)** Milk and milk products - Part XVI
- **q)** Pork - Part XVII
- **r)** Sheep and goat meat - Part XVIII
- **s)** Eggs - Part XIX
- **t)** Poultry meat - Part XX
- **u)** Agricultural ethyl alcohol - Part XXI
- **v)** Apiculture products - Part XXII
- **w)** Silkworms - Part XXIII
- **x)** Other products - Part XXIV

## ARTICLE 2 - General Provisions of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP)

For measures provided for in this Regulation, Regulation (EU) 2021/2116 of the European Parliament and of the Council and the provisions laid down thereunder shall apply.

## ARTICLE 3 - Definitions

### 1. Specific Definitions

For the purposes of this Regulation, the definitions contained in Annex II, which concern specific sectors, shall apply.

### 2. Common Definitions

For the purposes of this Regulation, the definitions provided in Regulation (EU) 2021/2116 and Regulation (EU) 2021/2115 of the European Parliament and the Council shall apply, unless otherwise provided in this Regulation.

### 3. Less Developed Regions

For the purposes of this Regulation, "less developed regions" means the regions as defined in Article 90(2), first subparagraph, point (a), of Regulation (EU) No. 1303/2013.

### 4. Adverse Climate Events

"Adverse climatic events that may be regarded as natural disasters" means conditions such as frost, hail, ice, rain or drought that destroy more than 30% of either:
- The average annual production of a given farmer for the previous three-year period, or
- The average of a three-year period calculated on the basis of the previous five-year period, excluding the highest and the lowest values

## ARTICLE 4 - Modifications to the Nomenclature of the Combined Tariff

When necessary to take account of modifications to the combined nomenclature, the Commission shall be empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 227 to adapt the description of products and references contained in this Regulation to the classes or distinctions of the combined nomenclature.

## ARTICLE 5 - Conversion Coefficients for Rice

### 1. Authority

The Commission may issue implementing acts to determine the conversion coefficients for rice at various stages of processing.

### 2. Procedure

Such implementing acts shall be adopted in accordance with the examination procedure referred to in Article 229(2).

## ARTICLE 6 - Marketing Years

The following marketing years are established for the various agricultural products:

- **Cereals:** August 1 to July 31
- **Rice:** September 1 to August 31
- **Olive oil:** November 1 to October 31
- **Wine:** September 1 to August 31

## AMENDMENTS AND MODIFICATIONS

This Regulation has been amended by the following:

| Regulation | Date | Official Journal |
|-----------|------|-----------------|
| (EU) No. 1310/2013 | December 17, 2013 | L 347 |
| (EU) 2016/791 | May 11, 2016 | L 135 |
| Delegated (EU) 2016/1166 | May 17, 2016 | L 193 |
| Delegated (EU) 2016/1226 | May 4, 2016 | L 202 |
| (EU) 2017/2393 | December 13, 2017 | L 350 |
| (EU) 2020/2220 | December 23, 2020 | L 437 |
| (EU) 2021/2117 | December 2, 2021 | L 435 |
| Delegated (EU) 2023/2464 | August 17, 2023 | L 2464 |
| (EU) 2024/1143 | April 11, 2024 | L 1143 |

## ARTICLE 225 - Reporting Obligations

The Commission shall submit reports to the European Parliament and to the Council:

- By December 31, 2025, and subsequently every seven years, on the application of competition rules in agriculture in all Member States
- By December 31, 2023, on EU market observatories established in accordance with Article 222a
- By December 31, 2023, and subsequently every three years, on the use of crisis measures
- By December 31, 2024, on the use of new information and communication technologies to ensure better market transparency
- By June 30, 2024, on denominations of sales and classification of carcasses in the ovine meat sector

## PART VI - POWERS, IMPLEMENTING PROVISIONS, TRANSITIONAL AND FINAL PROVISIONS

### CHAPTER I - Powers and Implementing Provisions

## ARTICLE 227 - Exercise of the Delegation

### 1. Conferral of Power

The power to adopt delegated acts is conferred on the Commission under the conditions set out in this Article.

### 2. Duration of Delegation

The power to adopt delegated acts conferred by this Regulation shall be granted for a period of seven years from December 20, 2013. The Commission shall draw up a report in respect of the delegation of power at the latest nine months before the end of the seven-year period. The delegation of power shall be tacitly extended for periods of an identical duration, unless the European Parliament or the Council expresses its opposition within three months before the end of each period.

### 3. Revocation

The delegation referred to in this Regulation may be revoked at any time by the European Parliament or the Council. A decision to revoke shall put an end to the delegation of power specified in that decision. It shall take effect on the day following that of publication of the decision in the Official Journal of the European Union or on a later date specified therein. It shall not affect the validity of delegated acts already in force.

### 4. Publication and Notification

As soon as it adopts a delegated act, the Commission shall notify it simultaneously to the European Parliament and the Council.

### 5. Entry into Force

A delegated act adopted pursuant to this Regulation shall enter into force only if no objection has been expressed by the European Parliament or the Council within two months from the date of notification of that act or if, before the expiry of that period, both the European Parliament and the Council have informed the Commission that they will not raise objections. The period shall be extended by two months on the initiative of the European Parliament or the Council.

## ARTICLE 228 - Urgent Necessity Procedure

### 1. Immediate Application

A delegated act adopted in accordance with this Article shall enter into force immediately and shall apply if no objection has been raised in accordance with paragraph 2. The notification of the delegated act to the European Parliament and the Council shall state the reasons for the use of the urgent procedure.

### 2. Objection Procedure

The European Parliament or the Council may raise objections to the delegated act adopted pursuant to this Article in accordance with the procedure laid down in Article 227(5). Should the European Parliament or the Council raise objections, the Commission shall repeal the act immediately upon receipt of notification of the objection decision from the European Parliament or the Council.

## LEGAL NOTE

This document is a documentation tool only and has no legal value. The authentic texts of the relevant acts, including their preambles, are those published in the Official Journal of the European Union and are available on EUR-Lex.

documents.title: REGULATION (EC) No. 1333/2008
documents.content:
# REGULATION (EC) No. 1333/2008

**Date:** December 16, 2008

**Subject:** On food additives

## PREAMBLE AND GENERAL PROVISIONS

This Regulation establishes rules for the use of food additives in the European Union. It harmonizes the rules governing food additives to ensure a high level of consumer protection, improve the functioning of the internal market, and provide clarity and transparency for food business operators.

### Objectives

The Regulation provides:

- A Community list of authorized food additives
- Rules for their use in food categories
- Classification and labeling provisions
- Procedures for evaluation and authorization

## CHAPTER I - GENERAL PROVISIONS

## ARTICLE 1 - Subject Matter

This Regulation lays down rules for the use of food additives in foods with a view to:

- Protecting human health
- Ensuring fair competition in the food industry
- Maintaining the functionality of foods
- Ensuring a high level of consumer protection

## ARTICLE 2 - Scope

This Regulation applies to food additives used in foods. It does not apply to:

- Substances added to foods for purposes other than food additive functions
- Residues of processing aids
- Substances used for essential technological purposes
- Nutrients added to foods under other regulations

## DEFINITIONS

### Food Additive

A food additive means any substance not normally consumed as a food in itself and not normally used as a characteristic ingredient of food, whether or not it has nutritive value, the intentional addition of which to food for a technological purpose in the manufacture, processing, preparation, treatment, packaging, transport or holding of that food results, or may be reasonably expected to result, in it or its byproducts becoming a direct or indirect constituent of the food.

### Authorized Food Additives

Food additives may only be used in foods if they:

- Have been evaluated and authorized
- Are used in accordance with specified conditions
- Are listed in the Community list of authorized additives
- Meet the purity criteria established

## REGULATION OF FOOD ADDITIVES

### E-Numbers

Approved food additives are assigned E-numbers (E followed by a three- or four-digit number):

- **E100-E199:** Colorants
- **E200-E299:** Preservatives
- **E300-E399:** Antioxidants and acidity regulators
- **E400-E499:** Thickening agents, gelling agents, and emulsifiers
- **E500-E599:** pH regulators and anti-caking agents
- **E600-E699:** Flavor enhancers
- **E700-E799:** Antibiotics (restricted use)
- **E900-E999:** Glazing agents, improving agents, and miscellaneous additives

### Categories of Food Additives

#### Colorants (E100-E199)

Used to restore or enhance the color of food:

- Tartrazine (E110)
- Sunset Yellow FCF (E110)
- Allura Red AC (E129)
- Carmine (E120)
- Beet Red/Beetroot Red (E162)
- Titanium Dioxide (E171)

#### Preservatives (E200-E299)

Used to prolong shelf life by protecting against deterioration caused by microorganisms:

- Sorbic Acid and Sorbates (E200-E203)
- Benzoic Acid and Benzoates (E210-E213)
- Sulfur Dioxide and Sulfites (E220-E228)
- Nitrates and Nitrites (E249-E252)

#### Antioxidants and Acidity Regulators (E300-E399)

Antioxidants protect food against deterioration caused by oxidation:

- Ascorbic Acid/L-Ascorbate (E300-E302)
- Tocopherols (E306-E309)
- Gallates (E310-E312)
- BHA and BHT (E320-E321)

Acidity regulators modify or control acidity or alkalinity:

- Citric Acid and Citrates (E330-E333)
- Malic Acid and Malates (E350-E353)
- Gluconic Acid and Gluconates (E370)

#### Thickening Agents, Gelling Agents, and Emulsifiers (E400-E499)

Used to modify texture and consistency:

- Gum Arabic (E414)
- Guar Gum (E412)
- Carrageenan (E407)
- Alginates (E400-E403)
- Pectin (E440)
- Xanthan Gum (E415)
- Lecithin (E322)
- Polysorbates (E432-E436)

#### pH Regulators and Anti-caking Agents (E500-E599)

- Sodium Carbonate/Bicarbonate (E500-E501)
- Potassium Carbonate/Bicarbonate (E501-E502)
- Calcium Carbonate (E170)
- Sodium Chloride (E536)
- Calcium Silicate (E552)
- Silicon Dioxide (E551)

#### Flavor Enhancers (E600-E699)

- Monosodium Glutamate (E621)
- Disodium Inosinate (E631)
- Disodium Guanylate (E627)

#### Miscellaneous Additives (E900-E999)

- Polydimethylsiloxane (E900) - anti-foaming agent
- Beeswax (E901) - glazing agent
- Shellac (E904) - glazing agent
- Microcrystalline Wax (E905) - glazing agent

## LABELING REQUIREMENTS

### Labeling in the Ingredient List

Food additives must be labeled in the ingredient list by:

- Their specific name (if it exists)
- Or their E-number
- Followed by the functional class (e.g., "colorant," "preservative," "emulsifier")

### Example Labeling Format

- "Tartrazine (E110)" or "E110 (Tartrazine)"
- "Sorbic Acid (E200)" or "E200 (Preservative)"
- "Guar Gum (E412)" or "E412 (Thickening Agent)"

## ARTICLE 3 - AUTHORIZATION OF FOOD ADDITIVES

### Procedure

Food additives may only be used if:

- They have been evaluated by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA)
- They have been included in Annex II (Community list of authorized additives)
- They are used in accordance with specified conditions
- They meet the purity specifications in Annex III

### Re-evaluation

The EFSA shall re-evaluate authorized food additives to ensure they continue to meet the criteria for safe use.

## ARTICLE 4 - PURITY CRITERIA

Food additives must meet the purity criteria specified in Annex III, which establish:

- Maximum levels of contaminants
- Microbiological limits
- Chemical specifications
- Methods of analysis

## AMENDMENTS AND MODIFICATIONS

This Regulation has been amended numerous times, with major amendments including:

| Regulation | Date | Official Journal |
|-----------|------|-----------------|
| (EU) No. 238/2010 | March 22, 2010 | L 75 |
| (EU) No. 1129/2011 | November 11, 2011 | L 295 |
| (EU) No. 1152/2013 | November 19, 2013 | L 311 |
| (EU) No. 1130/2011 | November 11, 2011 | L 295 |
| (EU) No. 232/2012 | March 16, 2012 | L 78 |
| (EU) No. 380/2012 | May 3, 2012 | L 119 |
| (EU) 2015/647 | April 24, 2015 | L 107 |
| (EU) 2020/1819 | December 2, 2020 | L 406 |
| (EU) 2022/63 | January 14, 2022 | L 11 |

## ARTICLE 5 - LABELING AND TRACEABILITY

### Food Business Operator Obligations

Food business operators must:

- Ensure proper labeling of food additives
- Maintain records of food additives used
- Provide traceability information
- Ensure compliance with use restrictions

### Consumer Information

Clear information about food additives must be provided on product labels and through ingredient lists.

## ARTICLE 6 - MONITORING AND ENFORCEMENT

### Member States

Member States shall:

- Monitor compliance with this Regulation
- Take enforcement action for violations
- Report on food additive use and safety
- Cooperate with the European Commission

### European Commission

The Commission shall:

- Oversee implementation
- Coordinate between Member States
- Consider requests for new food additives
- Issue guidance on application

## ENTRY INTO FORCE AND APPLICATION

This Regulation entered into force on January 1, 2009, and has been continuously updated with amendments to reflect new scientific evidence and market developments.

## LEGAL NOTE

This document is a documentation tool only and has no legal value. The authentic text is published in the Official Journal of the European Union and available on EUR-Lex.

documents.title: REGULATION (EC) No. 1334/2008
documents.content:
# REGULATION (EC) No. 1334/2008

**Date:** December 16, 2008

**Subject:** On flavouring substances and certain food ingredients with flavouring properties used in and on foods and amending Regulation (EEC) No. 1601/91 of the Council, Regulations (EC) No. 2232/96 and (EC) No. 110/2008 and Directive 2000/13/EC

## CHAPTER I - OBJECT, SCOPE AND DEFINITIONS

## ARTICLE 1 - Object

### Purpose

This Regulation establishes rules for flavouring substances and food ingredients with flavouring properties used in and on foods, with a view to ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market while at the same time ensuring a high level of human health protection and a high level of consumer protection, including the protection of consumer interests and fair food trade practices, and taking into account, where it is deemed necessary, environmental protection.

### Specific Objectives

For these purposes, this Regulation provides for:

**a)** A Community list of flavouring substances and source materials approved for use in and on foods, set out in Annex I (hereinafter referred to as "the Community list")

**b)** Conditions of use for flavouring substances and food ingredients with flavouring properties in and on foods

**c)** Rules on the labelling of flavouring substances

## ARTICLE 2 - Scope

### 1. Application

This Regulation shall apply to the following:

**a)** Flavouring substances used or intended to be used in and on foods, subject to more specific provisions provided for in Regulation (EC) No. 2065/2003

**b)** Food ingredients with flavouring properties

**c)** Foods containing flavouring substances and/or food ingredients with flavouring properties

**d)** Source materials for flavouring substances and/or source materials for food ingredients with flavouring properties

### 2. Non-Application

This Regulation shall not apply to:

**a)** Substances with exclusively sweet, sour or salty taste

**b)** Unprocessed foods

**c)** Non-compound foods and mixtures such as fresh, dried or frozen spices and/or herbs, tea mixtures and mixtures for infusions as such, provided they have not been used as food ingredients

documents.title: REGULATION (EC) No. 178/2002
documents.content:
# REGULATION (EC) No. 178/2002

**Date:** January 28, 2002

**Subject:** Laying down the general principles and requirements of food law, establishing the European Food Safety Authority and laying down procedures in matters of food safety

## PART I - GENERAL PRINCIPLES

## ARTICLE 1 - OBJECTIVE

This Regulation lays down general principles and requirements of food law, establishes the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), and lays down procedures in matters of food safety with the aim of protecting human health and consumers' interests, taking into account in particular:

- Food safety and integrity
- Animal health and welfare
- Plant health
- The environment
- Fair practices in food trade

## CHAPTER I - SCOPE AND DEFINITIONS

## ARTICLE 2 - SCOPE

### 1. General Application

This Regulation applies to:

- All stages of production, processing and distribution of food
- All stages of production, processing and distribution of feed
- Imported food and feed

### 2. Exclusions

This Regulation does not apply to:

- Primary production for private domestic use
- Food prepared for private domestic consumption

### 3. Special Cases

Specific provisions may apply to particular sectors as determined by the European Commission.

## ARTICLE 3 - KEY DEFINITIONS

### Definitions

For the purposes of this Regulation:

**Food:** Any substance or product, whether processed, partially processed or unprocessed, intended to be, or reasonably expected to be, ingested by humans. This includes drink, chewing gum and any substance, including water, intentionally incorporated into food during its manufacture, preparation or treatment.

**Feed:** Any substance or product, including additives, intended for animal feeding by oral ingestion.

**Food Law:** The laws, regulations and administrative provisions governing food in general, and food safety in particular, at European Union or Member State level. It applies to all stages of production, processing and distribution of food.

**Food Business:** Any undertaking, whether for profit or not and whether public or private, carrying out any of the activities related to any stage of production, processing and distribution of food.

**Food Business Operator:** The natural or legal person responsible to the competent authority for ensuring that food law requirements are met.

**Primary Production:** The production, rearing or cultivation of primary products including harvesting, milking, and transportation of live animals.

**Hazard:** A biological, chemical or physical agent in food, or condition of food, with the potential to cause an adverse health effect.

**Risk:** A function of the probability of an adverse health effect and the severity of that effect, consequential to a hazard.

## ARTICLE 4 - GENERAL PRINCIPLES

### Transparency and Information

Food business operators and competent authorities shall provide consumers with the information they need to:

- Make informed choices
- Understand food production and safety measures
- Know about any risks associated with food consumption

### Traceability

**One Step Back/One Step Forward:**
Food business operators shall be able to identify:
- The supplier of food or feed
- The immediate customer of their products

**Full Traceability:**
Competent authorities shall require traceability throughout the food chain when necessary to protect public health.

### Control and Responsibility

**Prevention First:**
Food business operators shall:
- Identify potential hazards
- Implement preventive measures
- Maintain control through documented procedures (HACCP principles)

**Responsibility and Accountability:**
Food business operators are responsible for ensuring compliance with food law and shall maintain documentation to demonstrate this.

## PART II - FOOD SAFETY REQUIREMENTS

## ARTICLE 5 - GENERAL FOOD SAFETY REQUIREMENTS

### Basic Obligation

Food shall not be placed on the market if it is unsafe.

### Food Safety Definition

Food is safe when it is fit for human consumption and does not cause illness or injury to consumers.

## ARTICLE 6 - CONSUMER PROTECTION FROM HAZARDS

### Prohibited Practices

Food shall not be placed on the market if it:

- Contains biological agents or their toxins at levels that are potentially harmful to health
- Contains pesticide residues or contaminants in excess of permitted limits
- Is below safe microbiological limits
- Is below safe chemical or physical safety standards

### Temperature Control

Where applicable, food shall be:

- Produced and handled at appropriate temperatures
- Stored and transported under proper conditions
- Protected against contamination

## ARTICLE 7 - FOODSTUFF INFORMATION AND TRACEABILITY

### Labeling Requirements

Food business operators shall provide information about:

- Identity and properties of the food
- Nutritional composition (where required)
- Potential risks to specific consumer groups
- Instructions for safe use and storage

### Record Keeping

Food business operators shall maintain records of:

- Sources of raw materials and ingredients
- Suppliers of feed ingredients
- Customers of food and feed products
- Processing records
- Temperature and humidity monitoring
- Cleaning and pest control
- Employee training records

## ARTICLE 8 - HAZARD ANALYSIS AND CRITICAL CONTROL POINTS (HACCP)

### Requirements

Food business operators shall:

- Identify potential hazards
- Determine critical control points (CCPs)
- Establish critical limits for each CCP
- Monitor CCPs
- Establish corrective actions
- Verify and validate HACCP procedures
- Keep records and documentation

### HACCP Principles

1. **Identify hazards:** Biological, chemical, and physical
2. **Determine critical control points:** Steps where control can be applied
3. **Establish critical limits:** Boundaries between safe and unsafe conditions
4. **Establish monitoring procedures:** For each CCP
5. **Establish corrective actions:** When limits are exceeded
6. **Establish verification procedures:** To ensure HACCP effectiveness
7. **Establish documentation:** To demonstrate compliance

## PART III - COMPETENT AUTHORITIES

## ARTICLE 9 - DESIGNATION OF COMPETENT AUTHORITIES

### Member State Obligation

Each Member State shall designate competent authorities responsible for:

- Implementation of food law
- Official controls
- Investigation of food-related incidents
- Enforcement of requirements

### Authority Functions

Competent authorities shall:

- Conduct official controls
- Monitor food business operator compliance
- Take enforcement action
- Report to higher authorities
- Cooperate with other Member States and the Commission

## PART IV - EUROPEAN FOOD SAFETY AUTHORITY

## ARTICLE 10 - ESTABLISHMENT OF THE EFSA

### Objectives

The European Food Safety Authority is established to:

- Provide scientific advice on food safety
- Perform risk assessments
- Provide rapid response to food safety crises
- Support Member States
- Communicate about food safety risks

### Tasks

The EFSA shall:

- Assess scientific evidence
- Provide opinions on food safety matters
- Advise the Commission and Member States
- Coordinate with international organizations
- Maintain scientific databases

## PART V - CRISIS MANAGEMENT

## ARTICLE 11 - EMERGENCY PROCEDURES

### Food Safety Alerts

When a serious risk to human health is detected:

- The affected Member State notifies the Commission
- The Commission informs other Member States
- Rapid Risk Assessment is conducted
- Coordinated action is taken

### Measures

Authorities may:

- Issue recalls
- Implement trade restrictions
- Establish temporary import bans
- Mandate reformulation or relabeling
- Suspend marketing

## PART VI - INFORMATION AND CONSUMER COMMUNICATION

## ARTICLE 12 - INFORMATION TO CONSUMERS

### Right to Information

Consumers have the right to:

- Know about food composition and properties
- Understand food production methods
- Be informed of food safety measures
- Learn about potential risks

### Communication

Food business operators and authorities shall:

- Provide clear and understandable information
- Respond to consumer inquiries
- Issue warnings about hazards
- Use accessible communication methods

## ARTICLE 13 - TRANSPARENCY

### General Principle

Food law shall be applied with a high degree of transparency to:

- Protect public health
- Maintain consumer confidence
- Ensure fair competition
- Facilitate international trade

### Information Exchange

The Commission shall maintain databases and systems for:

- Sharing information between Member States
- Reporting food safety incidents
- Coordinating rapid response
- Monitoring trends

## ENTRY INTO FORCE

This Regulation entered into force on February 28, 2002, and has been the foundational food law regulation for the European Union since then.

## AMENDMENTS AND KEY RELATED LEGISLATION

- Regulation (EC) No. 852/2004 - Hygiene of foodstuffs
- Regulation (EC) No. 853/2004 - Specific hygiene rules
- Regulation (EC) No. 854/2004 - Official controls
- Regulation (EU) No. 1169/2011 - Food information to consumers
- Regulation (EU) No. 1333/2008 - Food additives
- Regulation (EU) No. 1334/2008 - Flavoring substances

## LEGAL NOTE

This document is a documentation tool only and has no legal value. The authentic text is published in the Official Journal of the European Union and available on EUR-Lex.

---

**Official Journal Reference:** OJ L 31, 1.2.2002

**Language Versions:** Available in all official EU languages on EUR-Lex

**Consolidated Version:** Available on EUR-Lex with all amendments integrated

documents.title: REGULATION (EC) No. 1924/2006
documents.content:
# REGULATION (EC) No. 1924/2006

**Date:** December 20, 2006

**Subject:** On nutrition and health claims made on foods

## PREAMBLE

The European Parliament and the Council of the European Union, acting under the provisions of the Treaty establishing the European Community, particularly Article 95, have established this Regulation to harmonize the rules governing nutrition and health claims made on foods.

### Key Objectives

This Regulation aims to:

- Ensure a high level of consumer protection
- Facilitate consumer choice through clear and accurate labeling
- Establish uniform rules across the EU market
- Prevent misleading claims about food safety or health effects
- Harmonize national provisions that could hinder the free movement of foods

## CHAPTER I - SUBJECT MATTER AND SCOPE

## ARTICLE 1 - Subject Matter

This Regulation establishes rules for nutrition and health claims made on foods, whether they are made in commercial communications including advertising or on labeling, in order to ensure:

- A high level of protection for consumers
- The provision of information enabling consumers to make informed choices
- Fair competition in the food industry

## ARTICLE 2 - Scope

### Application

This Regulation applies to:

- **Nutrition claims:** Any claim that states, suggests, or implies that a food has particular nutritional properties
- **Health claims:** Any claim that states, suggests, or implies that a relationship exists between a food or one of its constituents and health

### Non-Application

This Regulation shall not apply to:

- Non-commercial statements or communications
- Published scientific literature
- Dietary guidelines issued by public health authorities
- Descriptions of common food use
- Traditional or generic descriptors (e.g., "digestive" or "cough drops")

## DEFINITIONS

### Nutrition Claim

A nutrition claim means any claim which states, suggests or implies that a food has particular beneficial nutritional properties due to:

- The energy (calorific value) it provides
- The nutrients it contains
- The nutrients it does not contain or contains in reduced form
- Nutrient content relative to other foods

### Health Claim

A health claim means any claim which states, suggests or implies that a relationship exists between a food category, a food, or one of its constituents and health, including claims of disease prevention or risk reduction.

## ANNEX - PERMITTED NUTRITION CLAIMS

### 1. ENERGY CONTENT CLAIMS

#### Low Energy
A claim that a food is low in energy, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the product contains no more than 40 kcal (170 kJ) per 100 g for solids or 20 kcal (80 kJ) per 100 ml for liquids.

#### Energy-Free
A claim that a food is energy-free, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the product contains no more than 4 kcal (17 kJ) per 100 ml.

### 2. FAT CONTENT CLAIMS

#### Low Fat
A claim that a food is low in fat, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the fat content does not exceed:

- 3 g per 100 g for solids
- 1.5 g per 100 ml for liquids

#### Fat-Free
A claim that a food is fat-free, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the product contains no more than 0.5 g of fat per 100 g or 100 ml.

#### Reduced Fat
A claim that a food has reduced fat content, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the fat content is reduced by at least 30% compared to a similar food, except where fat reduction is achieved by increased water content.

### 3. SATURATED FAT CLAIMS

#### Low Saturated Fat
A claim that a food is low in saturated fat, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where:

- The sum of saturated fat and trans fat does not exceed 1.5 g per 100 g for solids or 0.75 g per 100 ml for liquids
- Saturated fat does not exceed 10% of energy value

#### Reduced Saturated Fat
A claim that a food has reduced saturated fat, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where:

- The sum of saturated fat and trans fat is reduced by at least 30%
- The trans fat content is not increased

### 4. SODIUM/SALT CLAIMS

#### Low Sodium/Salt
A claim that a food is low in sodium or salt, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the sodium content does not exceed:

- 120 mg per 100 g for solids
- 120 mg per 100 ml for liquids

#### Sodium-Free/Salt-Free
A claim that a food is sodium-free or salt-free, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the sodium content does not exceed 5 mg per 100 g or 100 ml.

#### Reduced Sodium/Salt
A claim that a food has reduced sodium or salt, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the sodium content is reduced by at least 25% compared to a similar food.

### 5. SUGAR CLAIMS

#### Low Sugar
A claim that a food is low in sugar, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the sugar content does not exceed 5 g per 100 g for solids or 2.5 g per 100 ml for liquids.

#### Sugar-Free
A claim that a food is sugar-free, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the sugar content does not exceed 0.5 g per 100 g or 100 ml.

#### Reduced Sugar
A claim that a food has reduced sugar, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the sugar content is reduced by at least 30% compared to a similar food.

### 6. PROTEIN CLAIMS

#### High Protein Content
The claim that a food is high in protein, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where at least 20% of the energy value of the food is provided by protein.

#### Source of Protein
The claim that a food is a source of protein, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the product contains at least a significant amount of protein as defined in Annex to Directive 90/496/EEC.

### 7. VITAMIN AND MINERAL CLAIMS

#### Source of Vitamins and/or Minerals
The claim that a food is a source of vitamins and/or minerals, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the product contains at least a significant quantity of the vitamin(s) or mineral(s) as defined.

#### High Content of Vitamins and/or Minerals
The claim that a food is high in vitamins and/or minerals, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where the product contains at least twice the amount required for a "source" claim.

### 8. INCREASED NUTRIENT CONTENT

#### Increased Content of Nutrients (except vitamins and minerals)
The claim that a food has increased content of one or more nutrients, or any claim likely to have the same meaning for the consumer, may only be used where:

- The product meets the criteria for a "source" claim
- The nutrient content is increased by at least 30% compared to a similar food

## ARTICLE 3 - GENERAL REQUIREMENTS FOR CLAIMS

### Substantiation

All claims must be based on scientific evidence recognized by the EFSA (European Food Safety Authority).

### Prohibition on Misleading Claims

Nutrition and health claims must not:

- Be false, ambiguous, or misleading
- Create the impression that the food could treat, prevent, or cure human disease
- Imply that without the food, a balanced diet would be impossible

### Comparative Claims

Any comparative nutrition claim must clearly identify the food(s) being compared.

## ARTICLE 4 - AUTHORIZATION OF HEALTH CLAIMS

Health claims may only be used for foods if:

- They have been scientifically established
- They have been authorized by the EFSA
- They comply with conditions of use specified in the authorization
- The food contains the relevant nutrient in a significant quantity

## ARTICLES 5-21 - PROCEDURES FOR AUTHORIZATION

The Regulation establishes procedures for the assessment and authorization of health claims by the European Commission, taking into account scientific opinions from the European Food Safety Authority.

## AMENDMENTS AND MODIFICATIONS

This Regulation has been amended by:

| Regulation | Date | Official Journal |
|-----------|------|-----------------|
| (EC) No. 107/2008 | January 15, 2008 | L 39 |
| (EC) No. 109/2008 | January 15, 2008 | L 39 |
| (EU) No. 116/2010 | February 9, 2010 | L 37 |
| (EU) No. 1169/2011 | October 25, 2011 | L 304 |
| (EU) No. 1047/2012 | November 8, 2012 | L 310 |

### Corrigenda

| Corrigendum | Date | Official Journal |
|-----------|------|-----------------|
| L 12 | January 18, 2007 | L 12 |
| L 206 | August 7, 2007 | L 206 |
| L 160 | June 12, 2013 | L 160 |

## ENTRY INTO FORCE

This Regulation entered into force on December 20, 2006, and was applicable from January 1, 2007.

## LEGAL NOTE

This document is a documentation tool only and has no legal value. The authentic text is published in the Official Journal of the European Union and available on EUR-Lex.
